sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving coordination compounds.
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction between iron(III) chloride hexahydrate and sodium hydroxide to form iron(III) hydroxide and sodium chloride, given the following reaction equation and standard enthalpy values for the reactants and products:
FeCl3·6H2O(s) + 3NaOH(aq) → Fe(OH)3(s) + 3NaCl(aq)
ΔH°f FeCl3·6H2O(s) = -743.34 kJ/mol
ΔH°f NaOH(aq) = -469.11 kJ/mol
ΔH°f Fe(OH)3(s) = -1037.9 kJ/mol
ΔH°f NaCl(aq) = -407.3 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH°rxn = ΣΔH°f(products) - ΣΔH°f(reactants)

For the products, we have:
1 mol of Fe(OH)3(s) and 3 mol of NaCl(aq)

For the reactants, we have:
1 mol of FeCl3·6H2O(s) and 3 mol of NaOH(aq)

Now, we can plug in the given standard enthalpy values:

ΔH°rxn = [(1 × -1037.9) + (3 × -407.3)] - [(1 × -743.34) + (3 × -469.11)]

ΔH°rxn = [-1037.9 - 1221.9] - [-743.34 - 1407.33]

ΔH°rxn = [-2259.8] - [-2150.67]

ΔH°rxn = -109.13 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction between iron(III) chloride hexahydrate and sodium hydroxide to form iron(III) hydroxide and sodium chloride is -109.13 kJ/mol.
